analysis.raw_analysis:
1. TRANSFORMATION TYPE: Input and output sizes are identical in all examples (ratio 1:1); the cell-grid (thin gridline color) is preserved.

2. PATTERN: The filled cell-tiles (the 3x3 colored blocks inside the grid cells) are cyclically moved (rotated) to new cell positions while gridlines (color 3 or 8) and background 0 stay unchanged.

3. KEY CHANGES:
- Ex1: colors 6 and 4 are relocated between cell positions (3 stays, 0 stays).
- Ex2: colors 6 and 3 are moved to different cells (8 stays, 0 stays).
- Ex3: colors 4 and 2 are relocated to other cells (8 stays, 0 stays).

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
- All inputs share the same cell-grid structure; gridline color is constant per example (ex1: 3, ex2/3: 8). Background is 0.  
- They differ only by which 3x3 cell-blocks are filled and by the fill colors (ex1 uses 4 & 6, ex2 uses 3 & 6, ex3 uses 4 & 2).

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- All outputs preserve gridlines and background.  
- Every 3x3 cell is filled with one of the input non-zero fill colors; colors have been propagated into previously-empty 3x3 cells.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Rule: for each colored 3x3 tile in the input, propagate its color across its entire row and column of 3x3 cells (replace 0s), leaving gridlines (3 or 8) and background 0 unchanged.

1) Reference objects: the colored filled cell-blocks (multi-cell colored squares inside the grid cells) remain unchanged and act as the template.

2) Grid pattern: copy/tile that template to every same-aligned grid cell that is empty, preserving the cell-grid lines and background.

3) Objects: the filled grid-cell blocks (often a 3x3 colored patch with a distinct center) are the key recurring objects; their internal color layout is replicated across all grid slots.

=== GENERAL RULE ===
1) Treat the thin continuous lines as the grid (a single nonzero gridline color) and treat color 0 as the background; the gridline color and all background 0 pixels remain unchanged in the output.  
2) Consider each grid "cell" (the 3x3 pixel square bounded by the gridlines) as a unit object. In the input some cells are empty (all 0) and some cells are filled entirely with a single non-grid color (a uniform 3x3 block of a color like 4, 6, 2, 3, etc.).  
3) Collect the set (and order) of these filled 3x3 cell-objects and their colors from the input; do not alter their internal 3x3 pattern or their color values when copying.  
4) Fill every cell in the grid that is empty in the input by copying whole filled cell-objects from that collected set so that every previously-empty cell becomes a complete 3x3 copy of one of the input filled cells. The copies preserve the exact 3x3 layout and color (no mixing).  
5) The distribution of which filled cell-object goes to which formerly-empty slot follows the input scan order of the filled objects (left-to-right, top-to-bottom): take the filled cells in that order and tile/cycle them into empty cells in reading order, repeating the list as necessary until every empty cell is filled.  
6) All original filled cells keep their original position and appearance; only previously-empty cells gain copies. No new colors are introduced and gridlines/background remain identical to the input.

1) Treat the thin continuous lines as the grid (a single nonzero gridline color) and treat color 0 as the background; the gridline color and all background 0 pixels remain unchanged in the output.  
2) Consider each grid "cell" (the 3x3 pixel square bounded by the gridlines) as a unit object. In the input some cells are empty (all 0) and some cells are filled entirely with a single non-grid color (a uniform 3x3 block of a color like 4, 6, 2, 3, etc.).  
3) Collect the set (and order) of these filled 3x3 cell-objects and their colors from the input; do not alter their internal 3x3 pattern or their color values when copying.  
4) Fill every cell in the grid that is empty in the input by copying whole filled cell-objects from that collected set so that every previously-empty cell becomes a complete 3x3 copy of one of the input filled cells. The copies preserve the exact 3x3 layout and color (no mixing).  
5) The distribution of which filled cell-object goes to which formerly-empty slot follows the input scan order of the filled objects (left-to-right, top-to-bottom): take the filled cells in that order and tile/cycle them into empty cells in reading order, repeating the list as necessary until every empty cell is filled.  
6) All original filled cells keep their original position and appearance; only previously-empty cells gain copies. No new colors are introduced and gridlines/background remain identical to the input.
